div1.p: Carter discusses yellow fever-K:\Reed\transmission_8_24\01139011.XMLcarrying mosquitoes in Asia.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Victor G. Heiser, February 6, 1924
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
February 6, 1924.
Dear Doctor Heiser:
div1.p: Your letter of February 5th. just received.

1/ Aedes (Stegomyia) aegypti is reported all over the
Far East and in great abundance: The Phillipines: middle and South
Japan: Southern China: French Indo-China: the Dutch East Indies:
British India and Australasia--especially northern Australia.
This is from Ludlow: Van Dine (Phillipines): Edwards and probably
fifty others for the British possessions and men equally good
in the others.

2/ Long's impression is erroneous. So far aegypti is the
only mosquito that has been accused (and proven) to convey yel-
low fever. I have said, however, in at least 1/2 dozen places.
that, from analogy (too uncertain an argument to “tie to”) with
other host borne diseases, we would expect other species of the
same genus and sub-genus to convey yellow fever, and none of any
other. Nowhere save in America has any attempt been made, so
far as I know, either experimentally or by epidemiology, to test
whether other mosquitoes are vectors, and in America we have no
no
-2-
other species of the Stegomyia sub-genus save aegypti.

In my long paper, which I sent you for the Australians--and
which you probably had to send off unread--I went rather elabor-
ately into the probability of other Aedes Stegomyia in the Orient
conveying yellow fever (especially Alba picta) and said that if this
were so the problem of elimination in the Far East, and also in
Africa, would be much graver than in the Americas.

In this last connection I would be greatly your debtor if
you would advise me in what journal or Transactions this paper
was published--for I judge it has been published by now--and also
if you could get me several copies thereof as I am asked to file
one copy of all my writings on yellow fever in the Army Medical
Museum and, naturally, I wish to do the same for my own Service.
With very best wishes for your prospective trip,
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Dr. Victor G. Heiser,
Director for the East,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
